translated: Verses of the Elders 16.3
Verses of the Elders🔽The Twentieth Chapter
The First Chapter🔽Telakāṇiya
For a long time I was tormented by wind and heat,🔽Contemplating the Dhamma,
I did not attain peace of mind,
I asked ascetics and brahmins:
‘Who has gone beyond in the world,
Who has attained the state of deathlessness?
Whose Dhamma will I accept,

analyzed: parama attha vijānana  antar vaṅka gataḥ āsi
translated: The supreme knowledge of the ultimate truth?’🔽I was caught in the jaws
Like a fish in the bait,
Bound by Mahinda’s trap,
Like the asura Vepacitti.
I cling to it, I do not let go,
From this sorrow and lamentation,
Who in the world will release me from bondage,
And make me experience full enlightenment?

analyzed: samaṇam brāhmaṇam vā ka  ādi santam pabhaṅguna
translated: What ascetic or brahmin,🔽Who proclaims the destruction of birth,
Whose Dhamma will I accept,🔽The chariot that carries away aging and death?

analyzed: vicikicchā kaṅkhā ganthita  sa ārambha bala saññuta
translated: Bound by doubt and longing,🔽Endowed with the strength of violence,
Consumed by the madness of anger,
The destroyer of what has been attained.
Arisen from the bow of craving,
With two and fifteen parts,
See the great and terrible
If it remains after being split.
Not abandoning wrong views,🔽Stirred up by thoughts,
Pierced by that, I waver,
Like a leaf tossed by the wind.
Arising from within me,
Quickly it affects me;
The body with its six sense bases,
Where it always goes.
I do not see a skilled doctor
Who can remove this dart;
With a sword of various colors,
Not with anything else, out of doubt.

analyzed: kaḥ me asatthaḥ avaṇaḥ  sallam abbhantara passaya
translated: Who is my harmless, unblemished,🔽Dart-puller within my heart?
Not harming any being,
Will pull out my dart.
For he is the best physician,
The remover of poison;
For one fallen into the deep,
He shows the shore and a hand.
I am submerged in the body of the earth,
In the great dust that cannot be carried away;
Deceit, envy, and conceit,
Sloth, torpor, and anxiety.
Agitation, the rumbling of clouds,
The raincloud of the fetters;
The streams carry away wrong view,
Thoughts dependent on lust.
The streams flow in all directions,

original: latā ubbhijja tiṭṭhati;🔽Te sote ko nivāreyya,
analyzed: latā ubbhijja tiṭṭhati  te sote kaḥ nivāreyya
translated: The creeper grows and stands,🔽Who can stop the streams,
Who can cut the creeper?
Make a dam, good sir,
To stop the streams;
Don’t let the mind-made stream
Suddenly break the tree.
Thus for me, who was frightened,
From this shore to the other shore,
The Teacher, the weapon of wisdom, the protector,
Attended by the assembly of seers.
The ladder, the good, the pure,
The strong, made of the essence of Dhamma;
He placed it for me, who was being carried away,
And said to me: ‘Don’t be afraid.’
Having ascended the palace of the foundations of mindfulness,
I looked around,
What I had previously imagined,
The people who delight in (wrong) views.
And when I saw the path,
The boarding of the boat,
Without determining myself,
I saw the supreme ford.
The dart that arises from oneself,
Is manifested by the net of existence;
For the non-occurrence of these,
He taught the supreme path.
For a long time I had been thinking,
For a long time I had been determined;
The Buddha removed the knot for me,
is the remover of poison.”
… the elder Telakāni …
